prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Underpass Echo-Wocky

’Twas underpass, the concrete gloom,  
Did gyre and gimble in the shade;  
All mimsy were the ribbéd walls,  
And the echo-impish played.  

“Beware the Boomerang-Call, my son!  
The mouth that gulps, the throat that claps!  
Beware the Slurrish word, and shun  
The frumious thunder-slaps!”  

He took his voice-box in his hand,  
Long time the waffled note he sought—  
So rested he by the tunnel-tree,  
And waited while it wrought.  

And as in ogrish thought he stood,  
The Boomerang-Call with burble of lung  
Came doubling back with a rubbery crood,  
And maddened every rung!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The echo-blades went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He gallumphed down the track.  

“And hast thou slain the Boomerang-Call?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas underpass, the concrete gloom,  
Did gyre and gimble in the shade;  
All mimsy were the ribbéd walls,  
And the echo-impish played.

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fogglewake Fandango

’Twas fogladrift and the silverbrume  
Did wimber-gloom round spire and stack;  
All murklemoth were the housetume,  
And the gracklewinds queerged from crack to crack.  
“Beware the Mornfog, wandringroot!  
The jaws that drip, the claws that daw!  
Beware the Slumberbolt, and shun  
The dribledrakes of the Mi-ra-maw!”  

He took his tindledrung in hand;  
Long time the gnapplemant he sought—  
So rested he on a dewbuck band,  
And stood a-wallow in thought.  
And, as in milkenooze he stood,  
The Mornfog, eyes of moonclot dread,  
Came dripping through the splinterwood,  
And sprayed its spindrilt shed!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The tindledrung went snickersnort;  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  
“And hast thou slain the Mornfog, lad?  
Come clasp my beamish heart, ohho!  
O glistening day!” he chortled gay,  
And spongey sun did glow.  

’Twas fogladrift and the silverbrume  
Did wimber-gloom round spire and stack;  
All murklemoth were the housetume,  
And the gracklewinds queerged from crack to crack.

prompt: Create a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wyrm of Second-See

’Twas twixtoday, the halfwound hours
    Did shimmy on the wiggleck,
All flimdrum was the tick-trim, ours,
    The brindle minds began to smeck.

“Beware the Déjàwyrm, my brain!
    The stare that snares, the hush that hurls;
Beware the slip-flash flash again,
    And frabjous folds of old-spun worlds!”

He took his snicker-quill in hand,
    Long time the glishsome glare he sought—
So rested he by the what-yond tree
    And stood a-wonder in familiar thought.

And, as in ventclue stare he stood,
    The Déjàwyrm, with eyes of yore,
Came slinking through the thistled-brood,
    And burbled latches evermore!

Swip-swap! Swip-snap! The moments clack!
    The snicker-quill went blinky-blue!
He left it dead, and with its head
    He whispered “Wait—this happened too!”

“And hast thou felled the Déjàwyrm?
    Come flake my flinders, beamish skull!
Recollect! Recollect!” the calm
    Repetitive glimmers, never dull.

’Twas twixtoday, the halfwound hours
    Still shimmy on the wiggleck—
All flimdrum is the tick-trim, ours;
    The brindle minds still smeck, smeck, smeck.

Did gyre and gimble in the air: the tele-screen un-stairs.

“Beware the Conference-beast, my son! the snout that snarks, the jaws that yawn,  
Beware the Webex-Jubjub bird and shun the frumious PPT-mon!”

The pointer-beam went clicker-clack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He marched to the next Zoom-track.  

“And hast thou slain the Conference-beast?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boss!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
They chortled on the Skype-ish cross.  

’Twas brillig in the boardroom and the silver slidy chairs

poem:
The Cartographaloo
’Twas maptime and the twirling meres  
Did gyre and gimel on the chart;  
All foldery were the border-veers  
And compass-roses smart.  
“Beware the Cartographaloo, my son!  
The lines that leap, the legends that bite!  
The squiggling grid that swallows the sun,  
And carticules that snare the knight!”  

He took his cartopencil keen,  
Its graphite nib aglint with ink;  
He sought the land where none had been—  
Where longitudes and lattices link.  
He rested long by a meridian tree,  
Then whistled a scale-bar tune,  
Till Cartographaloo!—from longitude three—  
It bloomed like a paper moon.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
His pencilly blade went snicker-snack!  
He traced the coast, he shaded it blue,  
And left the beast a cartographic black.  
“And hast thou mapped the Cartographaloo?  
Come fold me, brave boy, in thy arms!”  
He crinkled his prize like a scroll anew,  
And danced with the creased-edge charms.  

’Twas maptime and the twirling meres  
Did gyre and gimel on the chart;  
All foldery were the border-veers,  
And compass-roses smart.

poem:
Layoverbay Banderollocks  

'Twas sweltering round the skyless bay,  
all tarpaulm did toil and flop;  
Skybusses bunkled down to stay,  
and porters gyred in swiveling tray  
the wheeled Somnambapath they’d prop.  

“Beware the harridove, young Pass!  
The beeps that bite, the snarling queues!  
Beware the Metaldroot and pass  
to Boardinggrate—grim silent mass—  
where Gatelet dragons snooze!”  

He took his carry-beld in paw,  
longtime lakeward curled his caff—  
To Layoverbay he came in aw  
where dreadlex sign did flick and gnaw,  
saying “Flightyants suffer—laugh!”  

And as in weary net he stood,  
the harridove with beacons bright  
came flapercrooning thro’ the hood  
of duty-free zebra’d plexiwoad,  
and purred of upgrades in delight!  

One two! One two! And through and through  
the straps went snicker-snack—  
He left it there, that growth of blue,  
then tumbled backward through the queue  
as tannoyed zeugmas routed back.  

“And hast thou slain the harridove?  
Come breathe my child, though lungs be leer!  
Oh frazzleglom day! Gatehove! Gatehove!”  
He lugged his adverbs up to shove  
inside the laughing tier.  

'Twas sweltering round the skyless bay,  
all tarpaulm still did toil and flop;  
He found his gate had phased away—  
Yet time itself rerouted play,  
and socks of hours filled the mop.

The Burnish Brawl

And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in uffish dusk he scrolled,

poem:
The Montemystic Fandangle

’Twas wintrous on the Monte wave, and velvet-vapor rolled;
The roulette-mabbles squeaked like jays, the croupiers glinted gold.
All flutter-bloomed the flambeaus high, like chandeliers unstrung,
While chiffon-churls in ruffled whurls for tippets’ tassels swung.

Beware the Croupiodrake, my son!   His talons tally chips;
He rakes the felt with silver rake, and bites the fingertips.
Tread softly through the baccarat glade—where green-lights ghostly go—
The Bankerphant may raise his trunk and trump the tables low.

He took his lucky talisman—a chip of cobalt glass—
He tossed it thrice in mirrored ice, then let it gently pass.
He sought the Dragoonte of Deal, whose whiskers shuffle cards,
Who speaks in clicks of riffling tricks inside forbidden yards.

And as in uffish neon glow he stood a-think to choose,
The Croupiodrake, with sequined shake, burst from the sequin ooze.
One two! One two! And hither-who! The chippings swirled like snow—
He bluffed the beast with blinding east of Kings he didn’t know.

He cleft the smoky mazard through, he left it gasping flat;
He scooped the pot, a sapphire lot, beneath a plumed cravat.
And hastened back by palmigrade through satin-lurking mist—
“It’s done!” he cried, his cravat wide, chip trembling in his fist.

’Twas wintrous on the Monte wave, and velvet-echo cried;
The roulette-mabbles hushed their squeaks, the croupiers merely sighed.
“Come claim thy winnings, fair famed boy; the tables have gone pale—
The Croupiodrake shall never wake; O frabjous day, all hail!”

The Browning of the Beurreybock

the milk-fat licked its golden chops,  
the gloozy whey did wibble-wop.

thy nose that sniffs the nut-brown smoke!  
Its caramelled claws, its bubbling locks,  
the sedgy scents that garble-groke!”

stirred long the glossy glooping land;  
she scritched and scratched till nubbles came,  
toasty swirls of amber-flame.  

All happablink, the foam grew fink,  
spattering tinkly amber-drink;  
between each slurp, the Beurreybock  
let slithery drool go slurple-slop.  

One, two! One, two! And through-and-through  
the whisk went wiggle-walloping too!  
She left it cool, she skimmed its ghosts,  
then piped the liquid into boasts.  

“Thou hast browned thy Beurreybock!”  
With nutty deed and nutty stock,  
she scromeled cakes, befrosted tarts,  
to frap her foes with buttery arts.  

’Twas melty in the copper pot;  
the nut-butter now house-warm and hot;  
the stove still purred, the platters glossed—  
such fraptious joy no crumb be lost!

**The Creepsome Slitherlow**

Though hushed its foot, its will it wills!”

Then rested in the plaster-land
And waited—déjà gone—then caught.

With leapish rust and mildew leer
Came Creepsome ozzing through the wall:
It twanged the laths with step-less leer,
It gribbled hinges, gums, and all.

One pixel-pinck! two, three! ah-four!
The nail-head noddled off anew;
He cambered left, it slithered more,
Till angle met what right once knew.

“And hast thou quelled the creep of fate?
Come clinch, my beamish borne anon!
O frabjous night! re-square! elate!”
He sealed it—yet the skew had gone.

The Whiffle-Whaffle Interloper

The Shutterwock

’Twas Lumnox, and the silver reels
Did gyre and gimbol in the bay;
So frabjous was the cellulose,
It ticked the tocks of yesterday.

“Beware the Shutterwock, my child!
The lens that bites, the flash that snares!
Beware the darkroom Velcro-goat,
And shun the filmwhoops’ blinding flares!”

He took his lightbox tirly sword,
Long rested in the tripod’s claws;
So Staggersome he filmwalked forth
Through celluloidian jabberlaws.

And as in technodream he slyph’d,
The Shutterwock through grain did run,
Non-chroming on a fogbright plain
With flashbulbs blatting like a gun.

One two! One two! Through f-stop clue
The tirly blade went snicker-snack!
He left it blind upon the rewind
And shorteroom-carrolled back.

“And hast thou slain the Shutterwock?
Come to my arms, my beamer boy!
O frabjous day! Kalôseh! Grey!”
He filmhoop’d in his joy.

’Twas Lumnox, and the silver reels
Did gyre and gimbol in the bay;
So frabjous was the cellulose,
It ticked the tocks of yesterday.

The Cartridge-Catch’s Clogged Calamity

   Did gyre and gimble in a stew;
All crumpled were the fuser flaps,
   And the toner drums were blue.

“Beware the Printerjam, my son!
   The jaws that catch! The claws that clutch!
Beware the Duplex-Dragon and shun
   The frumious Paper-Crutch!”

He took his Letter-Blade in hand;
   Long time the jammed foe he sought—
Then rested he by the toner tree
   And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
   The Printerjam, with maw askew,
Came whiffling through the output hood,
   And burbled as it chewed it through!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
   The Letter-Blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, yet still its dread
   Sprung threefold paper back.

“And hast thou slain the Printerjam?
   Come to my arms, my beamish tech!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
   The office gave him heck.

’Twas printerless, and the duplex tray
   Now wept and wobbled in its box;
Yet in the bin, white wraiths spin
   A never-ending flock of docs.

poem:
The Monte-Carlocky

’Twas brillig on the promenade,  
The yachts did gleam and glide;  
All flamboyant were the bougainvilleas,  
And the neon waves at Monaco-side.

The cards that snap, the dice that snatch!  
Beware the velvet bouncers, and shun  
The frumious high-stretch!”  

He took his lucky talisman tight,  
Long rested by the sea;  
So gallant he sought the Casino light—  
The Monte-man, not me!  

He swam through traffic’s tangled tide,  
Where Lambos snarled and growled;  
He wove through valets’ velvet glide,  
And through the gold-leaf crowd.  

“Thou hast not tipped enough, my lad?  
The valet’s frown runs deep—  
Come to my suite, where caviar’s had,  
And dreams no watchmen keep.”  

One, two! One, two! Through chandeliers bright  
The croupier’s fingers flew!  
Wheel spun, chips clattered, futures tight—  
O fabjous day and dew!  

He cashed his chips, he kissed his luck,  
He left the baccarat floor;  
Then danced till dawn with disco-dusk—  
A prince no more, yet more!  

“And hast thou slain the zero green?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Calooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas brillig on the Côte d’Azur,  
The yachts did gleam and glide;  
All flamboyant were the bougainvilleas,  
And the neon waves at Monaco-side.

The Cartographwockiad

Came whiffling through the topobrood  
With isogonic wings of night!

The stylus stroke went snicker-snack!

O frabjous lay—Cartograph!” he said,

poem:
The Fid-Banferous Fugue
’Twas after flute and piccolo had tripped the skylark scale,
   When solfa-doves in treble clefs took wing across the air;
Beneath the metronomic moon they drummed a dotted quail,
   And clattered chords like silver spoons on plates of purled ware.

Beware the Fid-Banferous, my son, the rosin-bearded beast,
   With horse-hair teeth and bow-spring claws that scritch and squall and squeal!
It swaps its A for empty C and gobbles every rest,
   Then burps up fugues in minor hues no human heart can heal.

He took his tuneful triquetra axe, and staff-slanted blade—
   The baton-sword of consonance that parts the dusk from dawn;
He quorum-dreamed in twelve-tone streams beneath the score-light shade,
   Till galloping glissandi rolled like thunder over lawn.

One, two! One, two! And sic passim! The chromatic duel grew loud,
   As staccato sparks lit breach-mark bars in fissures sharp and green;
At last the beast fell forte-flat beneath a chroma-crowd,
   And quavers faintly fluttered off where mute suspensions’d been.

“Hooray!” the trumpets tremored; the glockenspeeled with cheer,
   “The clarionet is done, the dreadful Fid-Banferous slain!”
They crowned the victor counterpoint with gold-embroidered tier,
   And minuets danced minnow-like through corridors of brain.

’Twas after flute and piccolo had slipped the skylark gate,
   And silence folded velvetlike across the cedar floor;
Yet if you lean your ear to wood, you’ll hear, both faint and late,
The beast’s soft syncopated breath still tapping evermore.

Flimfloppedéjà

prompt: Create a poem about stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Curtsey of the Curtained Dark

’Bware the curtain’s raspy swish— it swirls, it croaks, it spies!
It slithers through the fly-ring ropes and ties fast-slipping sighs.
Beware the Wingback Wyrm that hides where pulleys tick and groan,
Whose breath is dust of half-lit dreams and velvet midnight sown.

He flaps his tatter’d flannel wings, he whispers cues amiss;
The trapped moths blink like footlights in the hollow of abyss.
His eyes are dagger pricks of red where working-lamps grow dim—
He counts the heartbeats of the ghosts who wait behind the trim.

I sought him in the shadow-folds, where costume racks confess,
Past wig and crown and moulted mask, through moth-hole loneliness.
I braved the rack-tape brambles, where the counter-weights drop sad;
I clutched a prop-sword made of dreams— unsharpened, gilt, and mad.

“O Wingback Wyrm, reveal thyself!” I cried through canvas glooms;
The echo came like muffled drums from long-forgot costume rooms.
He lumbered from the cyc-line dusk, dim scrim-sheets round him curled;
He bowed—a courteous monster grim— then whisked me off the world.

We twirled on downstage starlight, we reeled through mottled wings;
He hummed the hush of curtain calls, the hush of parting strings.
Yet still I thrust with dream-sword blade, a gentle, gilded poke—
It bent like hope, it rang like doubt; ironically it broke.

He laughed a rusted pulley laugh, then softly blew a kiss:
A wisp of velvet epilogue, a sigh of greased abyss.
Back through the tab I tumbled, landing softly on my feet;
The house was dark, the play had died, my solo heart still beat.

And now when boards are empty, when only exit signs gleam,
I feel the Wingback’s phantom hug inside the black-winged dream.
’Ware the curtain, child of craft, ’ware the threadbare wink of night:
For stage wings flap in silences too deep for footlight.

The Interferocky

And static-heeded a lot.

The Interferock, with goggles of flood,  
Came scrawling from the wavican,  
Crackle-talk spitting its blood!

His spanner went snicker-snack!  
He dulled the beast’s blareful beep  
And clanged it flat on the track!

“And hast thou slain the Interferock?  
Come to my arms, my brightish boy!  
O frabjous day, free-calambley!  
He chortled an echo of joy!”

All klem were the radios, and the static reeled—

The Slithersheen

gave micro-sighs through briny stall.

long time the vise-grip rack he sought—  
then rested by the quartzite stand  
and micro-moused while in grim thought.

the Creep came crawling, slide by slide,  
with stress-smirk lips and lattice steep,  
it wrung the fault-edge yawning wide!

He left it stuck, fatigue askew,  
and came wan-smiling, buckling back.  
“And hast thou slain the Creep, my beam?

beneath the crust it stirs—oh hoi!

all cinker-shuddered in the crawl.  
Mineral moats with tectonic hope—

The Crumbletrack of Thwartled Skies

that writhed ’neath catacomb and spine.

her heart still beat the subway tune.

The Grumdrumble Underpass

poem:
The Printer-Jam of Blottery Bluk
’Twas half-past four, and the toners slim  
Did shimmy and shrink in the tray’s dim brim;  
All splotchy were the paper spooks,  
And the feed-roll growled a gritty “Scrooks!”  

Beware the Printer-Jam, my son!  
The claws that snatch, the teeth that gnash,  
The turgid toot of the drum’s dull crash!  
Shun the frumious Tonerplash!  

He took his vorpal drumstick white,  
Long time the jammed page sought he—  
So rested he by the blink-red light  
And stood a-while in puzzlery.  

And as in uffish hush he paused,  
The Printer-Jam, with smudge of dread,  
Came crinkling from the duplex maw,  
And mangled pages—left for dead!  

One, two! One, two! Through blots and tears  
The vorpal drumstick went snicker-snack—  
It jammed itself in jammed gears,  
And staggered back in hopeless wrack.  

‘And hast thou slain the Printer-Jam?  
Come grace my desk, thou chuffed lad!  
O flubberous day! All hail!’—But damn—  
He found the ink had started to run bad.  

’Twas half-past five, and the toners grim  
Did curdle and clot on the tray’s bent rim;  
All streaky were the paper crooks,  
And the feed-roll growled again: “Scrooks!”

Déjà Jabberwockery

Came scrimbling from the shadowed glade,
Replaying, spraing, once again!

One, two! One, two! and through and through
Sensation sliced like razely rhyme—
He blinked and found the future past,
A moment eaten twice by time.

“And hast thou slain the Déjà-Drake?
Come savour this recurrent cheer!
Beware, for echoes never end;
O frabjous day, we’re back in fear!”

’Twas duskling on the reminwold hill,
The slithy mem’ries breathed once more;
They snawkled through the still-seen mist—
As every footstep trod before.
